Fig. 2 (a) Powder XRD pattern of Ru-Ba/MgO100, Ru-Ba/MgO70, Ru-Ba/MgO30, and Ru-Ba/MgO5 catalysts. (b–e) HAADF-STEM image and EDS elemental mapping of the catalysts. (f–i) Particle size distribution for Ru of the catalysts. (b, f) Ru-Ba/MgO100, (c, g) Ru-Ba/MgO70, (d, h) Ru-Ba/MgO30, and (e, i) Ru-Ba/MgO5. Fig. 3 Ru dispersions obtained by H2 chemisorption and CO chemisorption for (a) Ru-Ba/MgOn and (b) Ru/MgOn catalysts. The curve shows the theoretical value obtained from Eq. (4). For the catalysts, d Ru,EM was applied for d Ru. Fig. 4 NH3 synthesis performance of the prepared catalysts. (a) WTYNH3 of Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts in the temperature range of 668–693 K. The inset shows WTYNH3 of Ru/MgOn catalysts at 678 K. (b) TOF at 678 K for Ru/MgOn and Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts. (c) Arrhenius plot and E a determination of Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts. (d) Reaction order analysis for NH3 of Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts. Fig. 5 (a) CO2-TPD profiles of MgOn and Ru-Ba/MgOn after He pretreatment. (b) CO2-TPD profiles of Ru-Ba/MgOn depending on the pretreatment condition (He or H2). (c) Ru 3d XPS of the Ru/MgO100, Ru-Ba/MgO100, and Ru-Ba/MgO5 catalysts after H2 pretreatment. Fig. 6 (a) NH3-TPD profiles of MgOn and Ru-Ba/MgOn after He pretreatment. (b) NH3-TPD profiles of Ru-Ba/MgOn depending on the pretreatment condition (He or H2). Fig. 7 Correlation between pellet radius and Mears number of the Ru-Ba/MgO100 catalyst at 678 K, 5 MPa, and N2/H2 = 1/3. The ρ cat,p is fixed to 630 kgcat. m−3. Fig. 8 (a) Correlation between pellet radius, Thiele modulus, and internal effectiveness factor. (b) Correlation between pore diameter and internal effectiveness factor with variation of pellet radius. The conditions are Ru-Ba/MgO100 catalyst, 678 K, 5 MPa, N2/H2 = 1/3, and the ρ cat,p is 630 kgcat. m−3. Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of sequential interactions, i.e. support–promoter and promoter–active center interactions, as well as catalytic consequences for Ru-BaO/MgO and Ru-BaO/AlO x catalytic surfaces. Graphical abstract The growing emphasis on decarbonization and the use of renewable energy has sparked considerable interest in ammonia (NH3) synthesis under mild conditions, accompanied by the concurrent development of catalysts. Among these catalysts, BaO-promoted Ru has often been reported as a highly efficient catalyst for this reaction. Despite MgO being traditionally regarded as an optimal support for this catalytic system, its precise role has remained ambiguous. This study aims to elucidate the specific role of MgO as a support for Ru-BaO catalysts. Using pure MgO and MgO-Al2O3 mixed oxide (MgAlO x ) with different MgO contents (MgO wt% = 5, 30, and 70) as supports, catalysts impregnated with equal amounts of Ba and Ru were prepared and analyzed to explore their NH3 synthesis activity and structural properties. Our observations reveal that while MgO does not directly promote Ru, it maintains robust basicity of BaO, enabling BaO to effectively function as an electronic promoter. In contrast, BaO supported on AlO x domain shows suppressed basicity, resulting in inertness as a promoter. Consequently, the Ru-Ba/MgO catalyst forms highly active Ru-BaO-MgO interfacial sites, leading to significantly higher activity, lower activation energy, and a distinct reaction mechanism compared to Ru-Ba/MgAlO x catalysts. This work sheds light on the importance of sequential interactions, i.e. support–promoter and promoter–active center interactions, in facilitating catalytic activity, thereby providing valuable insights essential for the design of advanced catalysts. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Ruthenium catalyst Magnesium oxide Electronic promotion Sequential interactions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) has played a pivotal role in advancing human advancement, serving as an important source for fertilizers and a wide range of industrial applications such as plastics, resins, coatings, and explosives. Currently, global NH3 production stands at approximately 200 Mt annually [1,2]. Forecasts predict a surge in demand, estimated to surpass annual 600 Mt by 2050 [2], due to NH3′s emergence as a high-density energy carrier and a carbon-free fuel [3–7]. Despite its societal importance, conventional ammonia synthesis via the Haber–Bosch process raises substantial environmental concerns as it uses fossil fuel-derived hydrogens, resulting in severe CO2 emission (>1.6 tCO2 tNH3 −1) [2]. To minimize greenhouse gas emissions and leverage green H2 for sustainable energy, attention has turned towards NH3 synthesis under milder conditions [8,9]. However, transitioning operation condition to milder temperature and pressure compromises reaction kinetics, highlighting the critical necessity for advanced NH3 synthesis catalysts. For over a century, Fe-based catalysts have been central to the Haber–Bosch process [10,11]. A notable commercial success after Fe-based catalyst is the Cs and/or Ba-promoted Ru/graphitic carbon catalyst employed in the Kellogg Advanced Ammonia Process (KAAP). This Ru catalyst shows superior activity compared to conventional Fe-based catalysts, reducing the severity of NH3 plant operation and therefore decrease the operation costs [12]. Regarding the reaction mechanism and the structural requirement of the active site, two hypotheses are widely accepted as the key claim of the active catalyst. First, considering NH3 synthesis over Ru is structure-sensitive [13,14], Ru particles with ca. 2 nm are known to be the best due to the abundance of B5 sites active for N2 dissociation (i.e. geometric effect) [14,15]. Second, electron-enriched Ru facilitates electron backdonation to reactant N2, thereby accelerating the dissociation of N≡N bond, the generally thought rate-determining step (i.e. electronic effect) [16–18]. Building on these premises, recent studies have introduced various materials such as alkali- or alkaline earth metal oxide/hydroxide [19–21], rare earth elements [22–24], electride [18,25,26], perovskite derivatives [27,28], alkaline earth amide [29], metal hydride [30], and N-doped carbon [31] as promoters and/or supports for Ru-based NH3 synthesis catalysts. Over the decades, the Ru/BaO/MgO composite has been considered as a promising composition for the NH3 synthesis catalyst, demonstrating high activity and long-term stability [16,32–37]. In particular, the superiority of MgO compared to other oxide supports is thoroughly addressed in a pioneering study by Aika and coworkers [32]. Furthermore, MgO stands out in many attractive points as a support due to its economic feasibility and high thermal stability. Many researchers have speculated that the superiority of MgO is attributed to its basicity, which promotes high electron density in supported Ru particles [38]. However, there are still some controversial perspectives on the role of MgO. Larichev et al. demonstrated the Ru particles supported on MgO have positive rather than negative charges through a rigorous X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study [39,40]. They argued that this feature is the reason for the necessity of the basic promoters. Recent studies from our group have elucidated that the Ru-BaO interfacial area primarily determines the NH3 synthesis activity of the Ru-Ba/MgO catalyst even at the same composition [35]. This interface facilitates the splitting of H atoms into H+/e− pairs, segregating them as H+@BaO and e−@Ru entities, thereby enriching the electron density of Ru and suppressing hydrogen poisoning. Further insights from density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated that MgO may not promote H splitting and separate storage due to its weak basicity [35]. In contrast, Tsang and his colleagues proposed the promoting role of the MgO(111) facet [34]. The authors suggested that MgO(111), which has an exceptionally high electrostatic polarity (i.e. basicity) compared to other MgO facets, is able to capture H+ to alleviate hydrogen poisoning of Ru particles and thus is beneficial for NH3 synthesis. These divergent observations stimulate curiosity about the genuine electronic promoting role of the MgO. This work aims to investigate the advantageous role of MgO as a support for Ru-BaO catalysts in NH3 synthesis. We undertake a comparative study using pure MgO and MgO-Al2O3 mixed oxide (MgAlO x ) supports with different MgO contents (MgO wt% = 5, 30, and 70). The catalytic activity shows a strong positive correlation with the MgO content of the support. A series of analyses reveal that MgO itself does not directly promote Ru, but it indirectly contributes to the promotion of the catalyst by imparting strong basicity to BaO, allowing BaO to play as an electronic promoter. This work highlights the pivotal role of sequential interactions, especially the support–promoter and promoter–active center interactions, in tailoring catalytic activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Mg-Al mixed hydroxy carbonate, i.e. PURAL MG5 (MgO:Al2O3 = 5:95), PURAL MG30 (MgO:Al2O3 = 30:70), and PURAL MG70 (MgO:Al2O3 = 70:30), were purchased from SASOL Chemicals. MgO (99.9 %) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Ba(NO3)2 (≥99 %), Ru3(CO)12 (99 %), and tetrahydrofuran (THF, HPLC grade) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. NaOH (>97 %) was purchased from Samchun Chemicals. 2.2 Catalyst preparation To prepare a porous MgO, 10 g of commercial bulk MgO was hydrothermally treated with 0.046 M NaOH aqueous solution at 353 K for 4 h with vigorous stirring and recovered by filtration and thorough washing until the supernatant solution reaches pH = 7. The recovered sample was dried at 373 K for 12 h, and then calcined in a muffle furnace at 823 K for 4 h under air flow. To obtain MgAlO x , the Mg-Al mixed hydroxy carbonates were calcined at 823 K for 4 h under air flow. The obtained samples are denoted as MgOn, where n is the MgO/(MgO + Al2O3) wt% in the precursor (n = 5, 30, 70, and 100). To synthesize Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts, Ba was first supported on the MgOn. Typically, 5 g of MgOn was impregnated with 1.307 g of Ba(NO3)2 dissolved in 50 cm3 of deionized (DI) water, and the solvent water was evaporated at 353 K under vacuum to load a nominal Ba content of 1.0 mmol gsupport −1. The Ba-impregnated sample was then thermally treated at 823 K for 2 h with N2 flow in a tube furnace. Next, 5 wt% Ru was impregnated on Ba/MgOn using Ru3(CO)12 as the Ru precursor. The 0.633 g of Ru3(CO)12 was first dissolved in 63 cm3 of THF, and vigorously mixed with 5.7 g of synthesized Ba/MgOn while evaporating the solvent at 323 K under vacuum. The dried sample was then reduced at 823 K for 2 h under H2 flow in a tube furnace. The ramp rate was 5 °C min−1 for all heat treatments. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The catalytic NH3 synthesis reaction was carried out in a stainless steel fixed-bed plug-flow reactor. Typically, 0.5 g of the sieved catalyst pellets (500–850 μm) were loaded into the reactor (3/8 in. inner diameter), and pretreated at 773 K for 2 h under N2/H2 (1/3 molar) mixed gas flow (50 cm3 min−1). After pretreatment, the reactor was conditioned to the target temperature and then pressurized under N2/H2 mixed gas flow (150 cm3 min−1). The catalytic activity was measured at 5 MPa, N2/H2 = 1/3, while varying weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) and reaction temperature. Unless otherwise noted, the results in this manuscript are measured at 4 h of time-on-stream, when the reaction has reached steady state. The outlet gas stream was monitored by a gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 6890N) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a Porapak Q column (Agilent). The weight-time-yield of NH3 (WTYNH3) over the catalyst is calculated using the following Eq. (1) [41]. (1) WTY NH 3 = c NH 3 1 + c NH 3 × M w NH 3 × WHSV 22400 where c NH3 is the NH3 concentration (0 ≤ c NH3 ≤ 1) of the outlet gas stream and Mw NH3 is the molecular weight of NH3 (i.e. 17 g mol−1). The apparent activation energy was determined by the Arrhenius equation while varying the reaction temperature from 668 to 693 K. The reaction order for NH3 was determined using Eq. (2) proposed by Hagen et al [42]. (2) ln P NH 3 = 1 1 - γ ln 1 F + C where γ is the reaction order for NH3, P NH3 is the partial pressure of NH3, and F is flow rate. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a SmartLab High Resolution (Rigaku) analyzer equipped with a Cu Kα (1.5406 Å) radiation source (200 mA and 40 kV). Peaks for standard materials were obtained using MATCH! phase analysis software. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the catalysts were obtained at 77 K using a Tristar II 3020 volumetric sorption analyzer (Micromeritics). Prior to measurement, the samples were degassed at 623 K for 5 h under vacuum conditions. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area (S BET) was calculated from the N2 adsorption curve at the P/P 0 = 0.05–0.25, and the total pore volume (V pore) was calculated at the P/P 0 = 0.99. High-resolution field emission transmission electron microscopy (HR-FE-TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) were measured using an F200 instrument (JEOL Ltd., Japan) at 200 kV acceleration voltage. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was performed using a JED-2300T EDS analyzer (JEOL Ltd.). All TEM micrographs were taken with a Rio 16 CMOS camera (Gatan). The surface-weighted average diameter of Ru particles (d Ru,EM) was determined using the following Eq. (3) by counting more than 100 Ru particles in HAADF-STEM images. (3) d Ru , EM = ∑ n i d i 3 ∑ n i d i 2 where ni is the number of particles with a diameter di . The dispersion of Ru particles was investigated by H2 and CO chemisorption using an ASAP2020 (Micromeritics) volumetric sorption analyzer. Prior to measurement, the samples were reduced at 673 K for 2 h under H2 flow and degassed at the same temperature for 2 h under high vacuum. The H2 and CO adsorption were performed at 323 K, and the chemisorbed amounts were determined by extrapolating the linear part of the isotherms (6–28 kPa) to zero pressure. Dispersion of Ru was obtained by assuming that the stoichiometric factors for Ru/H2 and Ru/CO are 2 and 1, respectively. The number of surface Ru atoms of the catalyst (N Ru surf) is calculated based on H2 chemisorption. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was measured using an AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics) instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Typically, 0.05 g of the sieved pellets (500–850 μm) were loaded into the U-shaped tube and pretreated with He or H2 flow at 673 K for 1 h, and then cooled down to the 323 K. Then, 10 % CO2/He was injected into the sample chamber for 1 h, and weakly bound CO2 was desorbed by He purging for 1 h at the same temperature. The desorption profile was measured from 323 to 973 K with a ramp rate of 20 K min−1 using He (30 cm3 min−1) as a carrier gas. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was measured in a similar manner using 10 % NH3/He as the adsorption gas instead of 10 % CO2/He. XPS was performed using an Axis-Supra (Kratos) equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation source (1486.7 eV). Prior to the measurement, all samples were pretreated by H2 flow at 773 K for 2 h and transferred directly to the analytical chamber without air exposure using a lab-made gas treatment system equipped with a glove box. Peak deconvolution was conducted by XPSpeak41 software. To deconvolute the Ru 3d–C 1s overlapped signals, the peak position of C 1s was fixed to 248.8 eV and a pair of Ru 3d 5/2 and Ru 3d 3/2 doublets with a spin–orbit splitting ratio of 1.5 and a binding energy gap (Δ) of 4.2 eV was used. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of MgO and MgAlO x supports A porous MgO, denoted as MgO100, was synthesized via a hydrothermal treatment of commercially available bulk MgO, followed by subsequent calcination. In addition, a series of MgO-Al2O3 mixed oxides—namely MgO70, MgO30, and MgO5, where the number indicates the weight percent of MgO in the support material (details are given in the experimental section)—were prepared by calcinating commercial Mg-Al hydroxy carbonates. The results of powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis are presented in Fig. 1 . MgO100 exhibits characteristic peaks at 2θ values of 36.8°, 42.8°, and 62°, which correspond to the cubic MgO crystal. MgO70 shows peaks related to those of cubic MgO, with notable shifts in the positions of MgO (200) and (220) peaks towards higher angles. This peak shift hints the formation of MgO-Al2O3 solid solution of which smaller Al3+ ion (68 pm) substitutes a lattice Mg2+ cation (86 pm) in the MgO. This substitution introduces an excess positive charge, necessitating the insertion of additional O2− ions near the Al3+ sites in stoichiometric amounts to maintain charge balance. The chemical formula of the MgO-Al2O3 solid solution, with a Mg:Al molar ratio of a:b, can be nominally represented as Mg a Al b O a +1.5 b . Consequently, structural alterations in the cubic MgO lattice, such as the presence of O adatoms, cation vacancies, and/or lattice disorder, may occur. The extent of peak shift becomes more pronounced as the Al content within the support material increases. The XRD pattern of MgO5 closely resembles that of γ-Al2O3, with Al2O3 being the major component (i.e. 95 wt%). MgO30 exhibits characteristic peaks of both Al-substituted MgO solid solution and γ-Al2O3, resulting in broader peaks compared to other MgOn materials. Conventionally, the calcination of Mg-Al hydrotalcite at temperatures above 973 K is known to result in the formation of MgAl2O4 spinel [43]. However, our analysis does not identify the presence of MgAl2O4 spinel, possibly due to the relatively lower calcination temperature of 823 K employed in our study. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm of the MgOn supports is shown in Fig. S1a. MgO100, MgO70, MgO30, and MgO5 have BET surface areas (S BET) of 32, 192, 235, and 250 m2 g−1, respectively. There is a discernible trend of increasing S BET as well as total pore volume (V total) with increasing Al content within the support material. BJH pore size distribution shows that samples with more Al have smaller pores, while MgO100, the pure MgO, has pores larger than 50 nm, suggesting the predominant presence of interparticular pores (Fig. S1b). 3.2 Characterization of Ru-Ba/MgO and Ru-Ba/MgAlO x catalysts In order to prepare NH3 synthesis catalysts, Ba and Ru were sequentially impregnated onto the MgOn supports. Nominally, the Ru content of the catalysts is 5 wt% and the Ba/Ru molar ratio of the catalysts is approximately 1.7 under the specified synthesis conditions. The N2 isotherm and corresponding pore structural properties of the Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts are shown in Fig. S2 and Table 1 , respectively. Although there is slight decrease in S BET and V total after Ba and Ru impregnation, the S BET and V total follow the same order as the supports: Ru-Ba/MgO100 < Ru-Ba/MgO70 < Ru-Ba/MgO30 < Ru-Ba/MgO5. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the XRD pattern of resultant Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts shows the characteristic peaks of BaO crystals (2θ = 24.2, 28.0, 34.5, and 45.0°). In particular, the BaO peaks are more prominent in Ru-Ba/MgO100 compared to other catalysts. Simultaneously, only Ru-Ba/MgO100 shows a peak indicative of Ru crystal (i.e. 2θ = 42.2°), indicating the formation of relatively large Ru particles. The other catalysts do not show any discernible Ru crystal peaks, signifying a high dispersion of Ru particles throughout the catalysts. Moreover, all catalysts retain the characteristic peaks of the support material (Fig. 1), indicating that the addition of Ba and Ru species does not alter the crystalline phase of the support. HAADF-STEM imaging coupled with EDS elemental mapping reveals that the BaO domain with an average layer thickness of 2 to 5 nm coats the MgO surface in Ru-Ba/MgO100 (Fig. 2b). Ru nanoparticles, ranging in size from 2 to 10 nm, are deposited on the BaO-coated MgO domain, establishing close proximity with the BaO particles. In contrast, BaO appears to be uniformly dispersed throughout the MgO-Al2O3 domain (Fig. 2c–e). On the Mg-deficient supports, the associations between Ru particle and BaO particle are not as distinct as Ru-Ba/MgO100. The Ru particle size is significantly affected by the type of support. Notably, as the Al content of the support increases, there is a gradual decrease in the average size of Ru particles (Fig. 2f–i). Specifically, in Al-absent Ru-Ba/MgO100, predominantly Ru nanoparticles with d Ru,EM = 6.81 nm are observed (Fig. 2b and 2f). In contrast, Ru-Ba/MgO5, with the highest Al content, exhibits a significant portion of atomically dispersed Ru species such as single atom, atomic clusters, and subnanometric clusters (Fig. 2e and 2i). This intriguing phenomenon can be attributed to the presence of γ-Al2O3 domain in the support. The γ-Al2O3 possesses coordinatively unsaturated penta-coordinated Al3+ centers that can strongly anchor the noble metal species [44,45], thereby stabilizing extremely small Ru clusters on the surface. Ru particles supported on MgO5 show a bimodal distribution, probably due to the size-dependent ripening and/or the heterogeneity of the surface of MgO5. The result indicates that beyond a certain threshold, i.e. 0.4 nm, Ru particles are facile to be sintered to a bigger particle during thermal processes. The dispersion of Ru was further characterized through H2 and CO chemisorption (Fig. 3 a). It is widely recognized that the dispersion of the metal particles is inversely correlated with the average particle diameter. The theoretical relationship between the average particle diameter (d Ru) and dispersion (D Ru) specifically for Ru is described as follows. (4) D Ru = 6 v Ru / a Ru d Ru × 100 % where v Ru is the volume of a single Ru atom in the bulk (i.e. 13.65 Å3), and a Ru is the area of a single Ru atom on the surface (i.e. 6.35 Å2) [46]. This equation is useful for the particles larger than about 1.3 nm. As confirmed during HAADF-STEM analyses (Fig. 2f–i), the prepared catalysts have an average Ru particle size (d Ru,EM) order of Ru-Ba/MgO5 < Ru-Ba/MgO30 < Ru-Ba/MgO70 < Ru-Ba/MgO100. However, the chemisorption results present that D Ru follows the order of Ru-Ba/MgO5 ≈ Ru-Ba/MgO30 ≈ Ru-Ba/MgO70 > Ru-Ba/MgO100 (Fig. 3a). The catalysts Ru-Ba/MgO5 and Ru-Ba/MgO30 show markedly lower values (ca. 50 %) compared to the theoretical values calculated from Eq. (4) (>86 %). Ru-Ba/MgO100 also displays significantly lower experimental values (5.3–9.1 %) than the theoretical value (19 %). To elucidate these counterintuitive observations, we prepared Ba-free control catalysts—namely, Ru/MgO5, Ru/MgO30, Ru/MgO70, and Ru/MgO100—and quantified their Ru dispersion. As depicted in Fig. S3, TEM analysis indicates that the Ru particle size distribution of Ru/MgOn is very similar to that of Ru-Ba/MgOn, suggesting the support primarily determines the Ru particle size distribution. H2 and CO chemisorption demonstrate that Ru/MgO5 and Ru/MgO30 again exhibit similar Ru dispersions (ca. 50 %) even in the absence of Ba (Fig. 3b), implying that excessively small Ru particles inherently show low chemisorption values. In other words, the known stoichiometric factors for Ru/H2 and Ru/CO are no longer applicable in small Ru clusters. In contrast, Ru/MgO70 and Ru/MgO100 demonstrate high consistency between theoretical and experimental values. In particular, Ru/MgO100 shows significantly higher dispersion (17–22 %; Fig. 3b) compared to Ru-Ba/MgO100 (Fig. 3a). The result indicates that densely coated BaO may hinder the access of probe molecules to the Ru sites in Ru-Ba/MgO100. The large disparity between H2 chemisorption (9.1 %) and CO chemisorption (5.3 %) in Ru-Ba/MgO100 reinforces this speculation as CO has larger kinetic diameter (3.8 Å) than H2 (2.9 Å) [47]. 3.3 Ammonia synthesis performance and reaction kinetic studies The NH3 synthesis performance of Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts was evaluated at 5 MPa, WHSV = 18,000 cm3 gcat. −1h−1, N2/H2 = 1/3 while varying the reaction temperature. The weight-time-yield of NH3 over the catalysts (WTYNH3) as a function of temperature is shown in Fig. 4 a. During the reaction, no deactivation was observed for about 8 h (Fig. S4a), and the TEM image of the used catalysts, Ru-Ba/MgO100 and Ru-Ba/MgO5, shows no significant changes in the Ru particle size distribution after the reaction (Fig. S4b and S4c). There is a positive correlation between the catalytic activity and the MgO content of the Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts (Ru-Ba/MgO5 < Ru-Ba/MgO30 < Ru-Ba/MgO70 < Ru-Ba/MgO100) in the temperature range of 668–693 K, confirming the superiority of MgO as well as the inferiority of Al2O3 as a support. For a comparison, the activity of Ru/MgOn catalysts at 678 K was also evaluated (inset in Fig. 4a). Typically, the catalysts show an order of magnitude lower activity compared to Ru-Ba/MgO100. In addition, there is only a marginal difference between the Ru/MgOn catalysts. These observations indicate that the support itself has a negligible direct effect on the activity of Ru. In turn, the turnover frequencies (TOF) for NH3 synthesis at 678 K of Ru/MgOn and Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts are represented in Fig. 4b. In the TOF calculation, the accessible Ru sites acquired by H2 chemisorption were used as the denominator. Firstly, all Ba-free Ru/MgOn catalysts exhibited relatively similar TOFs ranging from 6.3 to 16 molNH3 molRu surf −1 h−1, again confirming that the support composition does not hugely affect the catalytic activity for Ba-free Ru catalysts. However, there is a positive correlation between TOF and MgO content within the support for Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts. In particular, Ru-Ba/MgO5 showed a similar TOF (12 molNH3 molRu surf −1 h−1) to that of Ru/MgO5 catalyst (9.8 molNH3 molRu surf −1 h−1), indicating the negligible effect of the BaO promoter. Conversely, on supports such as MgO30, MgO70 and MgO100, the addition of Ba increased the TOF of the catalysts (Ru-Ba/MgOn > Ru/MgOn). Of note, the Ru-Ba/MgO100 exhibited a TOF two orders of magnitude higher (828 molNH3 molRu surf −1 h−1) than Ba-free catalysts. These results highlight the importance of the support composition on the catalytic activity of Ru-BaO composite catalyst, where MgO maximizes the efficacy of the BaO promoter while AlO x inhibits it. The effect of support composition on the catalytic activity was further investigated through a reaction kinetics study. The apparent activation energy (E a) gradually decreases from 154 kJ mol−1 to 42 kJ mol−1 as the catalyst contains higher MgO content in the support (Ru-Ba/MgO5 > Ru-Ba/MgO30 > Ru-Ba/MgO70 > Ru-Ba/MgO100; Fig. 4c). This trend reinforces the advantages of MgO support for accelerating NH3 synthesis compared to MgAlO x supports. The low activation energy of 42 kJ mol−1 is comparable to that of some state-of-the-art catalysts [38], suggesting the high potential of Ru-Ba/MgO for low-temperature applications. To better understand the role of support and Ba species, the apparent activation energy of Ba-free Ru/MgO100 was also measured. The result demonstrates that Ru/MgO100 shows a relatively high E a of 143 kJ mol−1 (Fig. S5), which is similar to that of Ru-Ba/MgO5 and Ru-Ba/MgO30. In addition, Fig. 4d shows the reaction order for NH3 (γ) of the Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts in NH3 synthesis. While most catalysts have γ around 0, only Ru-Ba/MgO100 has a huge negative value (−0.55) which indicates a strong interaction between NH3 and catalyst surface. All these observations point to the uniqueness of MgO as a support. Contrary to AlO x , MgO tailors the nature of Ru-BaO to be more active. Accordingly, it allows the NH3 synthesis to follow a much kinetically favored pathway. 3.4 On the role of MgO within Ru-Ba/support catalytic system Over the past four decades, extensive research has been dedicated to investigating the Ru/support and Ru/BaO/support systems. Throughout this period, numerous hypotheses have emerged in attempts to elucidate the active sites. Among these, the influence of Ru particle size, often referred to as the geometric effect, has been widely discussed as a critical parameter governing NH3 synthesis activity [14,15,31,48–51]. Early investigations by Jacobsen et al. underscored the structure sensitivity of Ru catalysts for NH3 synthesis, suggesting that Ru particles in the range of 1.8–2.5 nm maximize the probability of active B5 site formation [14]. Subsequent studies, such as those conducted by Raróg-Pilecka et al., have corroborated this trend in catalytic activity concerning the number of B5 sites in Ru particles <2 nm, yet discrepancies arise with larger Ru particles (>2 nm) [52]. It has been postulated that Ba may serve as a geometric promoter, facilitating the creation of additional B5 sites in relatively larger Ru particles. Recent investigations have introduced more nuanced perspectives on the geometric effect. For instance, Fernández et al. proposed that larger average Ru particles, along with a broad size distribution, are more effective for NH3 synthesis [48]. In contrast, Jiang and his coworkers demonstrated that smaller Ru particles exhibit superior performance in Ru/BaCeO3 [49] and Ru-Ba/N-doped C catalytic systems [50], with atomic Ru clusters possibly representing the optimal configuration [31]. The electronic effect represents another crucial aspect in elucidating the activity of Ru catalysts. In a study using Si3N4, MgAl2O4, and C as supports, Hansen et al. demonstrated that the impact of the Ba promoter varied significantly depending on the support type [53]. Specifically, the observed enhancement in catalytic activity following Ba addition could not be solely attributed to the Ru dispersion effect, emphasizing the significance of electronic promotion. Siporin and Davis further noted an increase in the turnover frequency (TOF) of Ru catalysts subsequent to the introduction of Cs, Ba, or La promoters, suggesting that these promoters primarily exert an electronic effect, leading to the creation of new highly active sites [37]. Our previous investigation strengthened this hypothesis by elucidating the specific active site which originates from hydrogen splitting [35]. It is often difficult to distinguish between geometric and electronic effects. For example, Jiang and co-workers who suggested the importance of the geometric effect, found that atomic Ru clusters are more electron-rich than Ru particles of other sizes [31]. Therefore, to comprehensively understand the role of MgO in the Ru-Ba/support system, it is imperative to discern the influence of both geometric and electronic effects. In our study, the Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts possess different Ru particle sizes, and the catalytic activity seemingly increases proportionally to the average Ru particle size. However, the particle size effect is unclear in Ba-free catalysts (Fig. S6), and the activity is heavily dependent on the presence of Ba. Thus, our observations align with some of the earlier viewpoint that the electronic effect, namely the interaction between Ru and BaO, can prevail over geometric effect and governs the catalytic activity of Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts. The interaction between Ru and BaO can be determined through CO2-TPD analysis of catalysts. To elucidate how it is affected by the support, we conducted CO2-TPD experiments on both pristine MgOn supports and Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts after pretreatment with He or H2 at 773 K (Fig. 5 a). In the CO2-TPD profiles of the supports (grey curves), the peak at 393 K for all samples can be attributed to weakly bound CO2 on the surface. The desorption signal in the range of 523–773 K indicates strongly bound CO2 on the surface. Notably, MgO100 displays higher CO2 desorption signals overall, as well as a larger fraction of strongly bound CO2 compared to the other supports. Meanwhile, MgO70, MgO30, and MgO5 show highly similar profiles each other. MgO100 has no peak above 823 K, while MgO70, MgO30, and MgO5 have a peak at 903 K. Since the supports were calcined at 823 K during the synthesis, the high temperature peaks can be assigned to the desorption of CO2 or H2O originally present in the hydrotalcite precursors. The CO2-TPD profiles of the Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts are also represented in Fig. 5a (red curves). All catalysts show a marginal increase in the low temperature peak compared to their respective supports. However, the increase in the high temperature signals (>473 K) is highly dependent on the support. The increment following the addition of Ba and Ru is more pronounced on the support with higher MgO content. Notably, Ru-Ba/MgO100 shows drastically increased CO2 desorption compared to MgO100, showcasing that the strong basicity is created after Ba addition. These results highlight the different nature of BaO depending on the support material. Contrary to the common belief that it is a strongly basic oxide, BaO is basic when in MgO but is hardly basic when supported on AlO x domains. The nature of active site for Ru-Ba/MgO100 was further studied. Notably, there are two sharp peaks in the TPD profile of Ru-Ba/MgO100, the peaks at 573 K and 843 K. Previous studies have indicated that the peak at 573 K represents the CO2 from Ru–BaO interface and the peak at 843 K indicates the CO2 from discrete BaO particles [35]. The CO2-TPD of Ba/MgO100 samples confirms the peak assignments (Fig. S7). Furthermore, the CO2-TPD analysis of the H2-pretreated Ru-Ba/MgO100 catalyst shows a depletion of the peak at 573 K compared to the He-pretreated one (Fig. 5b), presumably due to the splitting of hydrogen atoms (H·) into protons (H+) and electrons (e−) occurring at the BaO-Ru interface, indicating the titration of basic BaO sites (i.e. the creation of H+@BaO/e–@Ru entities). Meanwhile, for other catalysts, the change in CO2 desorption profile after H2 pretreatment is negligible, representing a limited interaction between Ru and BaO. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), involving H2 pretreatment at 773 K and excluding air exposure, was conducted to further investigate the electronic state of reduced Ru particles. The analysis focused on two catalysts, Ru-Ba/MgO100 and Ru-Ba/MgO5, chosen for their the most striking differences in catalytic activity. Additionally, Ba-free Ru/MgO100 was examined to differentiate the influence of Ba. In the Ru 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 5c), Ru/MgO100 exhibits peaks at 280.3 eV and 284.5 eV, corresponding to the typical peaks for Ru 3d 5/2 and Ru 3d 3/2 of metallic Ru, respectively. Notably, Ru-Ba/MgO100 displays a significant red shift (approximately 0.3 eV) in the Ru 3d peaks, indicating the electron accumulation on Ru particles facilitated by BaO. In contrast, Ru-Ba/MgO5 exhibits a Ru 3d distribution highly similar to that of Ru/MgO100, suggesting negligible electronic interactions between Ru and BaO. Similar results were observed in the Ru 3p XPS analyses (Fig. S8). Similarly, we performed TPD of NH3, which is a basic probe molecule as well as the product of the reaction of our interest. As shown in Fig. 6 a, MgO100 exceptionally shows the strongly bound NH3 signals (peak at 563 K) while MgAlO x supports (MgO70, MgO30, and MgO5) mainly show weakly bound NH3 signals. Notably, Ru-Ba/MgO100 exhibits significantly decreased NH3 desorption signals compared to MgO100, again confirming the strong basicity of BaO. However, all other Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts show similar TPD profile to their support, indicating the suppressed basicity of MgAlO x -supported BaO. Given that Al3+ possesses significantly higher electronegativity (1.513) than Ba2+ (1.126) [54], the basicity of BaO may be titrated by the Al2O3 domain, while the relatively neutral nature of MgO (electronegativity of Mg2+ = 1.234 [54]) tends to preserve the basicity of BaO. The effect of H2 pretreatment on the Ru-Ba/MgOn catalysts was also investigated in NH3-TPD (Fig. 6b). H2 pretreatment on Ru-Ba/MgO5, Ru-Ba/MgO30, and Ru-Ba/MgO70 catalysts hardly changes the high-temperature signals (>523 K). On the other hand, in the Ru-Ba/MgO100 catalyst, a large increase in the high temperature peak is noticeable after H2 treatment. That is, the surface of Ru-Ba/MgO100, more specifically, the H+@BaO and e–@Ru entities, exceptionally stabilizes the adsorption of NH3. This result is coherent with the reaction kinetics analyses that only Ru-Ba/MgO100 showed a highly negative reaction order for NH3, which could imply the stabilization of NH x intermediates. Combining all these observations can provide an understanding of the activity and apparent activation energies, which differ markedly depending on the MgO content of the support (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the Ru-BaO site interfacing with the AlO x domain may be a weak active site like bare Ru, since the BaO has lost its function as an electronic promoter. Such a site is likely vulnerable to hydrogen poisoning and presents a high energy barrier for activating inert N2 molecule. On the other hand, the Ru-BaO site in contact with the MgO domain is a strengthened active site where hydrogen poisoning is mitigated, N2 activation is facilitated, and NH x intermediates are possibly stabilized due to the efficient functioning of BaO as a promoter. This distinction suggests a potential alteration in the rate-determining step, signifying a substantial shift in the reaction pathway. The observations in our study robustly confirm the speculation that a basic or inert support is suitable for Ru-based NH3 synthesis catalysts [53]. Furthermore, these insights contribute to the understanding of efforts to promote Ba-containing Ru-based catalysts, particularly those that incorporate additional elements to enhance the basicity of Ba species [26,55,56]. 3.5 Investigation on the mass transfer limitations In order to understand the mass transfer property of the catalytic system, the effects of external and internal mass transfer limitations were evaluated using the Mears criterion and the Weisz–Prater criterion, respectively. First, the external mass transfer limitations can be ignored if the Mears criterion [Eq. (5)] is satisfied [57]. (5) M e a r s n u m b e r ( N Mears ) = - r A , obs × ρ c a t , p × R c a t , p × n k c × C A , b u l k < 0.15 where −rA ,obs is the observed reaction rate (kmol kgcat. −1 s−1); ρ cat,p is the catalyst pellet bed density (kgcat. m−3); R cat,p is the catalyst pellet radius (m); n is the reaction order of reactant A; k c is the mass transfer coefficient for reactant A at the given condition (m s−1); CA ,bulk is the concentration of reactant A in the bulk gas phase in kmol m−3. In this study, we use N2 as the molecule of interest as it is generally assumed that N2, a kinetically larger molecule than H2 may suffer diffusion limitation much easily. The detailed estimation procedure of each parameter is summarized in Table S1, and the obtained values of each parameter for the catalytic reaction at 678 K and 5 MPa are summarized in Table 2 . All Ru-Ba/MgOn catalytic systems have a Mears number (N Mears) significantly lower than 0.15 and thus satisfy the criterion. If we postulate that the observed reaction rate is an intrinsic property of the catalyst—the −r N2,obs has measured under the reaction kinetics-controlled regime—then the N Mears relies solely on R cat,p and ρ cat,p. While variations in R cat,p might affect ρ cat,p, our analysis reveals that ρ cat,p remains relatively constant across different pellet sizes (Fig. S9). Therefore, the N Mears can be expressed as a function of R cat,p, and their correlation for the Ru-Ba/MgO100 catalyst is shown in Fig. 7 . Our estimation indicates that a catalyst pellet radius of about 6.6 mm is the upper limit for Ru-Ba/MgO100 to exclude the external mass transfer limitations. The internal mass transfer limitation was studied by estimating the Weisz–Prater criterion. The Weisz–Prater number (N W–P) can be calculated by the following Eq. (6): (6) N W - P = - r A , o b s × ρ c a t , p × R c a t , p 2 D A , e × C A , s u r f ≪ 1 where −rA ,obs is the observed reaction rate (kmol kgcat. −1 s−1); ρ cat,p is catalyst pellets bulk density (kgcat. m−3), R cat,p is the catalyst pellet radius (m); DA ,e is effective diffusivity of reactant A near the catalyst surface (m2 s−1); and CA ,surf is the concentration of reactant A at the catalyst surface (kmol m−3). If N W–P is much smaller than 1, then we can determine the internal mass transfer limitation can be excluded. Furthermore, the N W–P and Thiele modulus (ϕ) has the following relationship [Eq. (7)]: (7) N W - P = η ϕ 2 where η is the internal effectiveness factor of the catalyst pellet. For a spherical pellet, the η can be expressed as Eq. (8) and therefore ϕ and η can be derived via Eq. (6) to Eq. (8). (8) η = 3 ϕ 2 ϕ coth ϕ - 1 Similarly, using N2 as the probe molecule, we have outlined in Table S2 the methods employed for estimating the parameters used in the Weisz–Prater criterion, with the corresponding values depicted in Table 3 . Notably, all Ru-Ba/MgOn catalytic systems exhibit a N W–P significantly below 1, indicating of minimal internal mass transfer limitations. At the same time, the values of ϕ are significantly less than 1 and η is approximately 1 for all catalytic systems. Since the internal mass transfer is hugely affected by the catalyst pellet size as well as the internal diffusivity of the reactant molecule, we aimed to obtain the criterion for the catalyst pellet size and pore size for the Ru-Ba/MgO100 catalyst to avoid internal diffusion limitation. Assuming that the other parameters are constant, we can estimate the values of ϕ and η as a function of R cat,p, which are shown in Fig. 8 a. The result shows that η can be greater than 0.95 if R cat,p is less than 23 mm. Combining the results from Figs. 7 and 8a, it can be concluded that both external and internal mass transfer limitations can be avoided when the pellet radius of Ru-Ba/MgO100 is less than 6.6 mm. Finally, the η was calculated by simultaneously varying the pellet radius (R cat,p) and the pore diameter (d p) of the Ru-Ba/MgO100 catalyst. For this study, only d p > 3 nm were examined because the mean free path of N2 under reaction conditions is about 3 nm (Table S3). We first fixed the R cat,p to 0.313 mm (i.e. the typical experimental condition) and estimated the η as a function of d p. The result demonstrates that the η is close to 1 regardless of the d p (Fig. 8b). Similar examinations were carried out for R cat,p = 3 mm and 6.6 mm, respectively. As the pellet size increases, the effectiveness factor becomes smaller especially in the small pore range (<10 nm). Nevertheless, for a pellet with R cat,p = 6.6 mm (i.e. the maximum size for which external diffusion limitation can be negligible), the effectiveness factor remains above 0.94 even with a minimum d p of 3 nm. This indicates a negligible influence of pore size on internal diffusion limitation. In fact, powder, pellets sieved at 500–850 mm, and pellets sieved at 1.0–1.5 mm for Ru-Ba/MgO100 all show similar activity (Fig. S10), supporting this conclusion. Although our approach is highly simplified, we expect this method can provide a useful tool for deriving the approximate porosity and pellet size of the technical catalyst body for practical applications. 4 Conclusion Through a comparative investigation of Ru-BaO catalysts impregnated on supports with different MgO contents, our findings highlight the pivotal role of support composition in catalytic activity. The Ru-Ba/MgO catalyst yields superior NH3 synthesis activity, significantly lower activation energy, as well as different reaction order compared to Ru-Ba/MgAlO x catalysts, showcasing the critical role of MgO in maximizing the catalytic performance of Ru-BaO. While MgO hardly promotes Ru directly, it primarily maintains robust basicity to the deposited BaO. This empowered BaO can serve as an effective electronic promoter for Ru, establishing strong active e−@Ru/H+@BaO sites that accelerate NH3 synthesis by mitigating H poisoning, facilitating N2 activation, and NH x stabilization. In contrast, the presence of AlO x domains within the MgO-Al2O3 mixed oxide appears to compromise the basicity of BaO, thereby hindering its role as a promoter, forming weak active site which has similar activation energy with non-promoted Ru. This study sheds light on the often ambiguous role of MgO as a support for Ru-BaO catalysts in NH3 synthesis. MgO contributes to the promotion of the catalyst through a domino effect. From a broader perspective, this work offers a valuable insight, emphasizing that understanding the sequential interactions between catalytic components is critical for rational catalyst design. At last, diffusion limitation studies have shown that Ru-Ba/MgO catalyst can bear a relatively wide range of effective pellet radius which reaches about a few mm, while pore size has minimal effect on diffusion limitation. coredata.dc:description: The growing emphasis on decarbonization and the use of renewable energy has sparked considerable interest in ammonia (NH3) synthesis under mild conditions, accompanied by the concurrent development of catalysts. Among these catalysts, BaO-promoted Ru has often been reported as a highly efficient catalyst for this reaction. Despite MgO being traditionally regarded as an optimal support for this catalytic system, its precise role has remained ambiguous. This study aims to elucidate the specific role of MgO as a support for Ru-BaO catalysts. Using pure MgO and MgO-Al2O3 mixed oxide (MgAlO x ) with different MgO contents (MgO wt% = 5, 30, and 70) as supports, catalysts impregnated with equal amounts of Ba and Ru were prepared and analyzed to explore their NH3 synthesis activity and structural properties. Our observations reveal that while MgO does not directly promote Ru, it maintains robust basicity of BaO, enabling BaO to effectively function as an electronic promoter. In contrast, BaO supported on AlO x domain shows suppressed basicity, resulting in inertness as a promoter. Consequently, the Ru-Ba/MgO catalyst forms highly active Ru-BaO-MgO interfacial sites, leading to significantly higher activity, lower activation energy, and a distinct reaction mechanism compared to Ru-Ba/MgAlO x catalysts. This work sheds light on the importance of sequential interactions, i.e. support–promoter and promoter–active center interactions, in facilitating catalytic activity, thereby providing valuable insights essential for the design of advanced catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Unraveling the role of MgO in the Ru-Ba/MgO catalyst for boosting ammonia synthesis: Comparative study of MgO and MgAlO x supports
